title: What is the distinction between the external and integral consciousness in the processes of common consciousness?
first_phrase: In this text, the author discusses the different processes of consciousness and how they relate to the brain. The center of the cycle of consciousness is the brain, which acts as a complex of recorders and distributors of facts and acts. However, in certain cases, the cycle can have the sympathetic nervous system as its center, leading to a lack of distinct perceptions. The external consciousness, manifested through the brain, is different from the integral consciousness, which is immediate and intellectual. The author provides a schema of three phases of degradation and three orders of dynamisms, which correspond to different types of consciousness.

last_phrase: In conclusion, understanding the three levels of consciousness, as well as the three phases of degradation or reintegration of spiritual energy, is essential to categorize the various processes of consciousness. By recognizing the corresponding elements of each phase, such as the ego, body, and animating forces, one can better understand the complex interplay of stimuli and reactions that occur within the human organism. This knowledge can lead to a deeper understanding of oneself and others, and ultimately to a more fulfilling life.
